book.title: GT version GRAM4 : System Administrator's Guide

abstract.title: Introduction
abstract.para: This guide contains advanced configuration information for system administrators working with GRAM4. It provides references to information on procedures typically performed by system administrators, including installation, configuring, deploying, and testing the installation. It also describes additional prerequisites and host settings necessary for GRAM4 operation. Readers should be familiar with the Key Concepts and Implementation Approach for GRAM4 to understand the motivation for and interaction between the various deployed components.

important.simpara: The information in this GRAM4 Admin Guide is in addition to the basic Globus Toolkit prerequisite, overview, installation, security configuration instructions in the . Read through this guide before continuing!

chapter.title: Building and Installing
chapter.para: GRAM4 is built and installed as part of a default GT version installation. For basic installation instructions, see .

section.title: Transport Level Security (TLS)
section.para: In order to use GRAM4, the container must be started with Transport Level security. The "-nosec" option should *not* be used with globus-start-container.

section.title: Functioning sudo
section.para: installingprerequisitessudo installingprerequisitessudo GRAM4 requires that the sudo command is installed and functioning on the service host where GRAM4 software will execute.

Authorization rules will need to be added to the sudoers file to allow the GRAM4 service account to execute (without a password) the scheduler adapter in the accounts of authorized GRAM users. For sudo configuration details, see the Configuring section.
Platform Note: On AIX, sudo is not installed by default, but it is available as source and rpm here: AIX 5L Toolbox for Linux Applications

section.title: Local Scheduler
section.para: GRAM4 depends on a local mechanism for starting and controlling jobs. Included in the GRAM4 software is a Fork scheduler, which requires no special software installed to execute jobs on the local host. However, to enable GRAM4 to execute and manage jobs to a batch scheduler, the scheduler software must be installed and configured prior to configuring GRAM4.

section.title: Scheduler Adapter
section.para: GRAM4 depends on scheduler adapters to translate the GRAM4 job description document into commands understood by the local scheduler, as well as monitor the jobs.
Scheduler adapters included in the GT version release are: PBS, Condor, LSF
Third party schedulers adapters available for GT version are: Sun Grid Engine
For configuration details, see "Configuring scheduler adapters" in the Configuring section.

section.title: GridFTP
section.para:
Though staging directives are processed by RFT (see next section), RFT uses GridFTP servers underneath to do the actual data movement. As a result, there must be at least one GridFTP server that shares a file system with the execution nodes. There is no special process to get staged files onto the execution node before the job executable is run.
See the "Non-default GridFTP server" section of for details on how to configure GRAM4 for your GridFTP servers used in your execution environment.

section.title: Reliable File Transfer Service (RFT)
section.para:
GRAM4 depends on RFT to perform file staging and cleanup directives in a job description. For configuration details, see .
Important: Jobs requesting these functions will fail if RFT is not properly setup.

chapter.title: Security Options
chapter.para: GRAM4 leverages the Globus Java WS Authentication and Authorization framework. In GT 4.2, a chain of multiple policy information points (PIPs) and policy decisions points (PDPs) can be configured for any GT 4.2 WSRF Service, GRAM4 included.
By default, GRAM4 is configured to use the built in GridMapAuthorizationPDP. Then an admin just has to create a gridmap file in order to authorize all GRAM4 job requests.

However, the authorization framework in 4.2 allows community specific PIPs and PDPs to be developed and configured with GRAM4.
A community specific PIP written for OSG and EGEE authorization interoperability is the Execution Service PIP. It collects information about the submitted job. Then the job information can be used with the XACMLAuthzCallout PDP to authorize the job request. The benefit here is to enable finer grain authorization decisions. For example, a subset of user's can be authorized to use a specific job service, like "Fork/immediate", while all users are allowed to use the "batch/cluster" job service.
